sdata.e: Fan letters lay in a heap on the desk.

sdata.e: Which do you like better, the sea or the mountains?

sdata.e: A series of blasts reduced the laboratory to ruins.

sdata.j: ↑後↑↓ご↓は↑野↑↓の↓となれ↑山↑↓|やま↓と|なれ。
↑後先↑↓あとさき↓↑考↑↓かんが↓えず、とりあえずやってみるか。↑後↑↓あと↓は↑野↑↓の↓となれ↑山↑↓|やま↓と|なれ、だよ。

sdata.e: I have heard that long ago, in a place near our village called Nakayama, there was small castle where the prince Nakayama lived.

sdata.j: ↑大和言葉↑↓|やまと|ことば↓は、↑日本↑↓にほん↓で↑昔↑↓むかし↓から↑使↑↓つか↓われてきた↑言葉↑↓ことば↓で、↑外国↑↓がいこく↓↑語↑↓ご↓に↑翻訳↑↓ほんやく↓し↑易↑↓やす↓いものもあれば、し↑難↑↓にく↓いものもあります。
sdata.e: Yamato-kotoba is the language that has been used in Japan since ancient times, and whilst it has some phrases that can be easily translated into foreign language, there are also those that are difficult.
